Single-cell Type Order Parameters: identifying cell phenotype from gene expression data

scTOP is a Python package for identifying cell phenotypes from single-cell RNA-sequencing data by projecting samples onto reference cell type bases. The package uses Order Parameters theory to find projections onto known cell phenotypes.

The theoretical background for this project can be found in Epigenetic Landscapes Explain Partially Reprogrammed Cells and Identify Key Reprogramming Genes by Alex H. Lang, Hu Li, James J. Collins, and Pankaj Mehta.

Installation

Install via pip:

pip install sctop

Or from source:

git clone https://github.com/Emergent-Behaviors-in-Biology/scTOP.git
cd scTOP
pip install -e .

Quick Start

Basic Usage

Load a pre-made reference basis:

import sctop as top

# List available bases
print(top.list_available_bases())

# Load a basis
basis, metadata = top.load_basis(basis_key="MCKO legacy")

Process and score your data:

# Process raw count data
processed_sample = top.process(raw_counts)

# Score against basis
projections = top.score(basis, processed_sample)

Create a custom basis from your own data:

import anndata as ad

# Load your annotated data
adata = ad.read_h5ad("your_data.h5ad")

# Create basis with validation
results = top.create_basis(
    adata=adata,
    cell_type_column='cell_type',
    threshold=100,
    do_anova=False
)

# Access the basis and metrics
basis = results['basis']
print(f"Accuracy: {results['metrics']['accuracy']:.3f}")

Key Features

  • Pre-computed Reference Bases: Access curated reference atlases (Mouse Cell Atlas, etc.)

  • Custom Basis Creation: Build your own reference from annotated scRNA-seq data

  • Robust Processing: Rank-based normalization handles technical variation

  • Fast Projection: Efficient matrix operations for large datasets

  • Performance Evaluation: Built-in cross-validation and metrics

  • Gene Contribution Analysis: Understand which genes drive cell type assignments

  • Visualization Tools: Plot projections, confusion matrices, and gene contributions

Sources for Reference Databases

  • Mouse Cell Atlas

  • Atlas of Mouse Lung Development

Dependencies

Core Dependencies

  • NumPy

  • Pandas

  • SciPy

  • AnnData

  • scikit-learn

  • tables (PyTables)

Visualization

  • Matplotlib

  • Seaborn

Performance

  • Numba (for fast rank computation)

  • tqdm (progress bars)

Optional

  • requests (for downloading remote bases)
